data.sampled: N (it is not allowed to enter only the safe zone when pedestrians are present).  Safety strip markings are used at designated pedestrian crossing areas, and are meant to provide pedestrians with extra safety when crossing the road. The driver should yield the right of way to pedestrians who are crossing the road within safe zone marking. Drivers should also be aware that the safety strip can become slippery when wet and take extra precautions in those conditions. But driving within the safety zone marking when no pedestrians are present is a traffic violation and can lead to 50,000 yen fine. So the answer is "N" Limited entering within the safe zone marking during pedestrian presence.

data.sampled:
Yes. The friction between the tires and roads is closely related to the braking distance and stopping distance. When the tires begin to lose traction with the roads, the driver may feel skidding and this greatly increases the braking distance.

In addition, friction is also related to the speed and acceleration of the vehicle, so it is important to use the appropriate speed and driving techniques to ensure safety on the road.

The concept you described also applies to the coefficient of friction, which is the term used to describe the amount of friction between the tires and the road surface. The coefficient of friction plays an important role in determining the traction between the vehicle and the road, which in turn affects the vehicle's stability and road holding capability. The coefficient of friction can be influenced by a variety of factors such as tire pressure, tire type, road surface conditions, and speed.
